WAYANAD

Wayanad is a district in the north-eastern part of Kerala, known for its natural beauty, wildlife, and culture. It is a place where you can explore the lush green hills, the pristine waterfalls, the ancient caves, and the diverse flora and fauna of Kerala. Here are some of the tourist attractions in Wayanad district that you can visit:

Banasura Sagar Dam: This is the largest earthen dam in India, and the second largest in Asia, built across the Karamanathodu River, a tributary of the Kabini River. It is situated at the foot of the Banasura Hill, and offers a spectacular view of the surrounding landscape. You can enjoy a boat ride on the reservoir, or indulge in some adventure activities, such as trekking, camping, and zip-lining. The dam also has a park, a garden, and a childrens play area

Chembra Peak: This is the highest peak in Wayanad, and one of the most popular trekking destinations in Kerala. It is located at an altitude of 2,100 meters above sea level, and offers a breathtaking view of the Wayanad valley and the nearby hills. The trek to the peak is challenging but rewarding, and takes about 3 to 4 hours to complete. The highlight of the trek is the heart-shaped lake, called Hridaya Saras, which is believed to be perennial

Edakkal Caves: These are two natural caves located on the Ambukutty Mala, and are considered to be one of the oldest sources of human civilization in India. The caves have rock carvings and paintings that date back to the Neolithic and Mesolithic periods, and depict various animals, humans, and symbols. The caves are also associated with many legends and myths, and are believed to be the abode of Lord Rama and Goddess Sita

Kuruva Island: This is a river delta island, formed by the confluence of the Kabini River and its tributaries. It is spread over 950 acres of land, and is rich in biodiversity. You can find a variety of plants, trees, herbs, orchids, and birds on this island, as well as some rare species of butterflies and insects. You can also enjoy a bamboo raft ride on the river, or a walk on the hanging bridge that connects the island to the mainland
